data.title: Slicing Through Dimensions: On Gravity in Edwin Abbott’s ‘Flatland’ and the Fabric of Spacetime Reality

data.text:
When I was thirteen years old, I picked up for the first time Edwin A. Abbott’s novel ‘Flatland’. It was a time when I was surrounded by timeless sci-fi novels and films, that thrilled me with surreal worlds in exciting narratives reaching beyond my dreary everyday reality, in the sultry summer heat of a small township in the heart of the turbulent Middle East. That was 1980, when the pictures of Abbott’s three-dimensional sphere sliced in by the two-dimensional universe, let me ponder about a strange kind of ‘fluidity of the dimensions’ that might govern a general universe, from within and from beyond of our own physical world.
